repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Improving access to clean water
            and sanitation

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            improving the access to clean water and sanitation in
            Cambodia. In 2001, Cambodia had a population of around 12.3
            million, with 20 percent of people living in urban areas.
            Coverage of improved water supply was extremely low, and
            institutional capacity in the utilities was virtually
            non-existent. Urban sanitation was even more under-served
            than urban water supply. For rural water supply and
            sanitation, low coverage, low efficiency and the lack of a
            clear development strategy remained key challenges. Cambodia
            Provincial and Peri-Urban Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project provided 90 percent of the residents with a reliable
            water supply in the country. The project was implemented by
            Phnom Penh Water Supply Authority (PPWSA) to expand its
            water network to target areas while supporting low-income
            communities in urban centers through access to clean water
            and sanitation.

repnme.cdata!: Rehabilitating the urban water sector in Cambodia

abstracts.cdata!:
Between 1998 and 2004, the Urban Water
            Supply Project supported the turnaround of two water
            utilities of Cambodia. The Phnom Penh Water Supply Authority
            (PPWSA) became a financially viable public enterprise
            operation under commercial law. 750,000 people gained access
            to water supply services in Phnom Penh. The Sihanoukville
            Water Supply Authority (SWSA) became more autonomous in its
            operations and extended water supply services to 18,000
            people within its poor service area. By 2004, both utilities
            improved their operational and financial performance
            substantially. The project also assisted in developing a
            national water supply and sanitation policy to foster
            sustainable well performing and autonomous public utilities.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Water Supply Project for
            Cambodia had the following ratings:  the outcome was highly
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, the Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory and borrower performance
            was satisfactory.  Among the lessons learned are the
            following:  1) More efforts should have been expended at
            preparation to identify a solution to Sihanoukville Water
            Supply Authority's (SWSA's) lack of autonomy. The
            Bank may have erred in repeatedly requesting autonomy
            without exploring other more realistic avenues, such as
            simple management contracts. 2) Disappointed by the small
            amount of flexibility enjoyed by SWSA, during the
            preparation of the successor project in 2000 the Bank
            decided not to include in the latter urban water systems
            without sufficient autonomy, and therefore to discontinue
            its involvement in Sihanoukville. In hindsight, the
            Bank's exit was probably premature and, as
            implementation progressed after 2000, it became increasingly
            clear that this had been a mistake. 3) Phnom Penh Water
            Supply Authority's (PPWSA' s) leadership was to a
            very large extent the driving force behind the whole
            project, as it created a dynamic benefiting all
            stakeholders. It also had a powerful demonstration effect.
            4) Project implementation would have benefited, if, before
            start of project execution, key personnel from the central
            and technical ministries had been provided assistance and
            training in Bank policies and procedures. It would have
            reduced delays. To the extent possible, this type of
            assistance should be on a grant basis. 5) The experiences
            accumulated from the project plead for a continued
            Bank's presence in the water and sanitation sector in
            Cambodia to consolidate what was achieved and to expand much
            needed services to a very poor population.

5081351.trustfund:
TF039272-CAMBODIA - URBAN WATER SUPPLY PROJECT,TF033737-ASIA REGION - WATER SUPPLY,TF033726-CAMBODIA - URBAN WATER SUPPLY,TF035250-EAST ASIA REGION - MEKONG BASIN FINANCING,TF033708-CAMBODIA - URBAN WATER SUPPLY,TF034089-CAMBODIA - WATER SUPPLY
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF035101-ASIA REGION - WATER, SEWERAGE SECTOR,TF033899-EAST ASIA - MEKONG BASIN
5081351.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Water Supply Project seeks to:
            a) improve drinking water coverage, quality and access in
            Cambodia's two biggest cities; b) improve the
            performance of the water utilities in these cities; c)
            enhance availability of water for commercial and industrial
            purposes in these two cities as a spur to economic growth
            and as a means of ensuring viability of the utilities; and
            d) help the Government develop and implement an investment
            program based on a well-articulated water and sanitation
            sector policy framework.  The project consists of three
            components: 1) Augmentation of water supply in Phnom Penh
            will be done through rehabilitation and extension of the
            Chruoy Chang War water treatment plant; supply of pipes,
            ancillary equipment and leak detection equipment; and
            technical assistance.  2) Augmentation of water supply in
            Sihanoukville will be done by raising the outlet weir and
            sealing off the sand spit to increase the storage of raw
            water; constructing four new groundwater wells; and
            improving distribution system.  3) Assistance to develop a
            water and sanitary policy framework for the sector as a
            whole will be provided through financing of consulting services.
